Fig. 1 XRD patterns of catalysts. (a) As-received Pt/C; (b) Pt/C after reaction; (c) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after reaction; (d) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after 4 uses. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images (A and B) and EDX analysis (C and D) of catalysts after reaction. (A) Pt/C (†: Larger (> 4 nm) particles are also present but omitted in the histogram because of the fewer number and aggregated shape); (B–D) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2. Reaction conditions: p-cresol (1.9 mmol), 50 wt% CH3COOHaq (9.8 g), Pt/C (0.175 g; 0.09 mmol), Pd(CH3COO)2 (0 or 35 mg; 0 or 0.16 mmol), air (0.5 MPa), 353 K, 1 h. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Pt L 3-edge X-ray adsorption spectra of catalysts and reference compounds. (A) XANES spectra. (B) Fourier-transform of EXAFS spectra (FT range: 30-160 nm−1). (a) Pt foil; (b) Na2Pt(OH)6; (c) as-received Pt/C; (d) Pt/C after catalytic use; (e) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after catalytic use. The EXAFS oscillations and inverse Fourier transform of filtered spectrum are shown in Figure S1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Pd K-edge X-ray adsorption spectra of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after catalytic use and reference compounds. (A) XANES spectra. (B) Fourier-transform of EXAFS spectra (FT range: 30-160 nm−1). (a) Pd foil; (b) PdO; (c) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after catalytic use. The EXAFS oscillations and inverse Fourier transform of filtered spectrum are shown in Figure S2, Supplementary Material. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Structure model of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of catalysts after control experiments. (a) C support (FAC-10 activated carbon); (b) Pd(CH3COO)2 + C after reaction with p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol (reaction conditions: Pd(CH3COO)2 35 mg, p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol 1.9 mmol, FAC-10 activated carbon 0.175 g, 50 wt% acetic acid aq. 9.8 g, 353 K, under Ar, 2 h); (c) Pt/C after reaction of p-cresol (Table 1, entry 2; same as Fig. 1(b)); (d) Catalyst after reaction of Pd(CH3COO)2 with the oxidation mixture of p-cresol over Pt/C (procedure: after the reaction of Table 1, entry 2, Pd(CH3COO)2 (35 mg) was added to the reaction mixture at room temperature, and then the mixture was heated at 353 K under Ar for 2 h); (e) Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after reaction of p-cresol (Table 1, entry 3; same as Fig. 1(c)). Department of Applied Chemistry School of Engineering Tohoku University 6-6-07 Aoba Aramaki Aoba-ku Sendai 980-8579 Japan Graphical abstract Oxidation of benzylic position in alkylphenols with molecular oxygen in acidic conditions, which is very difficult because of the intense dimerization or polymerization, was investigated with various combinations of noble metal catalysts. The combination of Pt/C and Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts showed activity in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation from p-cresol. The best p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield was 35%, which was obtained in 50 wt% aqueous acetic acid, Pt on carbon : Pd(CH3COO)2 weight ratio = 1 : 2, at 353 K. From XRD, TEM-EDX and XAFS characterizations, the Pt and Pd species were totally reduced to Pt and Pd metal particles, respectively, in spite of the oxidative reaction conditions. Polymerized products (“tar”) of p-cresol formed with Pt/C catalyst and air can be the reductants for Pd(CH3COO)2 into Pd metal. The catalysts or catalyst combinations without Pd metal showed no activity in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde, suggesting that Pd° is the active species. The effects of the air pressure and presence of radical scavenger were very small, suggesting that non-free-radical mechanism was involved. Keywords Cresol Aerobic oxidation Palladium Platinum 1 Introduction Alkylphenols, especially p-isomers such as p-cresol and p-propylphenol, are components of coal tar [1,2] and biomass tar (also called as “bio-oil”) [3–5], and they can be also produced by decomposition of lignin [6–11]. Therefore, alkylphenols are important organic non-petroleum resources. Among various conversion methods of alkylphenols, oxidation of alkyl chain produces useful building blocks such as p-hydroxybenzaldehyde from p-cresol. However, direct oxidation of the alkyl chain in alkylphenols is rather difficult because of the high reactivity of phenolic ring; tarry polymers are frequently produced via the coupling of phenolic rings [12–16]. This forms a marked contrast to the alkylbenzene oxidations: selective oxidation at the benzylic position of alkylbenzenes is possible with free-radical autoxidation [17,18] or redox reaction over solid catalysts [19–23]. There are several reports for aerobic oxidation of p-cresol to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde using transition-metal-oxide catalysts, such as oxides of Co [12,14,16,24–30], Mn [31] and Cu [13,32,33], combined with excess base (typically NaOH; ∼4 equiv.); however, the necessity of the neutralization of the excess base is a serious problem. Another oxygenation method of alkyl group in alkylphenols is the indirect process involving chlorination and hydrolysis [34], and this method also produces stoichiometric amount of salt during the hydrolysis step. Therefore, the development of aerobic oxidation of the side chain of alkylphenols in neutral or acidic conditions is highly beneficial to the production of biomass-derived chemicals, although no such system has been reported, to the best of our knowledge. Considering the general difficulty in controlling selectivities of radical-based oxidation [12–16,35,36], the selective oxidation of alkylphenols should not involve free radicals. In this study, we develop a noble-metal-catalyst-based aerobic oxidation system of methyl group in p-cresol (Eq. (1)) in water/acetic acid media. The combination of Pt and Pd catalysts markedly improves the selectivity. (1) 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts Commercially available noble metal catalysts on activated carbon (Wako) were used as received: 10 wt% Pt/C (dispersion determined by CO adsorption, CO/Pt = 20%), 5 wt% Ru/C (CO/Ru = 35%), 5 wt% Rh/C (CO/Rh = 22%) and 5 wt% Pd/C (CO/Pd = 14%). The additive salts were commercially available and used as received: palladium(II) acetate (Wako), palladium(II) nitrate (N.E. CHEMCAT), nitroxoruthenium(III) nitrate (Sigma Aldrich), hexachloroiridic acid (Furuya Metal), and rhodium(III) nitrate (Wako). Shirasagi FAC-10 (Osaka Gas Chemicals) was used as noble-metal-free activated carbon. Ir/C (5 wt%) was prepared by impregnation of FAC-10 activated carbon with aqueous hexachloroiridic acid solution and heating at 573 K under N2 atmosphere. The dispersion of Ir determined by CO adsorption (CO/Ir) was 95%. Two types of Pt-Pd/C catalysts (Pt-Pd/C(Cl) and (Pt-Pd/C(N)) were prepared by co-impregnation method with two different set of precursors: H2PtCl6 + PdCl2 and [Pt(NH3)4](NO3)2 + Pd(CH3COO)2, respectively. After impregnation, the Pt-Pd/C catalysts were heated at 573 K under N2 atmosphere for 1 h, reduced at 473 K with flowing H2 for 1 h, and then passivated with 0.2%O2/He at room temperature. The loading amounts of both catalysts were 9 wt% Pt and 9 wt% Pd. The dispersion determined by CO adsorption (CO/(Pt + Pd)) was 9.3% and 0.8% for Pt-Pd/C(Cl) and Pt-Pd/C(N), respectively. The low dispersion of Pt-Pd/C(N) was probably due to the remaining acetate species adsorbed on the metal surface. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The oxidation reaction was performed in 190 mL autoclave reactor with an inserted glass vessel, unless noted. Typically, substrate (p-cresol, 0.2 g), supported noble metal catalyst (10 wt% Pt/C, 0.175 g), co-catalyst (Pd(CH3COO)2, 35 mg), solvent (50% CH3COOH aq, 9.8 g) and stirrer bar were loaded into the glass vessel. The vessel was set into the reactor, and pressurized with 0.5 MPa air. The reactor was heated to the set value (353 K), and when the temperature reached almost the set value (set temperature - 5 K) we started counting the reaction time. The reactor was stirred at 250 rpm during the experiment. After appropriate reaction time, the reactor was rapidly cooled down, and the autoclave content was collected to a vial. The autoclave was washed with 2-propanol, and the liquid was added to the collection vial. The internal standard substance (mesitylene) was also added to the collection vial. The samples were analyzed by GC (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with FID and DB-35 capillary column. In selected cases the gas phase was also collected to gas bag and analyzed by GC (Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with methanator, FID and Porapak N packed column). The formation of gaseous products such as COx was negligible in all the cases including the case at the highest reaction temperature (393 K) in this study. The conversion was calculated by [(initial amount of substrate (mol)) – (remaining amount of substrate (mol)]/(initial amount of substrate (mol)) × 100%. The yield of each product was calculated by [produced amount of the product (C-mol)]/(initial amount of substrate (C-mol)) × 100%. For the products that cannot be identified with GC–MS, the carbon number and the molar sensitivity were assumed to be the same as those of the substrate. In most runs, there was large loss of carbon balance, which was mainly due to the formation of polymer or tar; the reaction solution became dark brown or black, and even black solid was sometimes formed. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were recorded with Rigaku MiniFlex600 diffractometer. TEM and EDX images were taken with Hitachi HF-2000EDX. The CO adsorption amount was measured in pulse method at 308 K with MicrotracBEL BELCAT-II instrument. The sample was pre-reduced with H2 flow at 473 K except the case of Ir/C which was pre-reduced at 573 K. The TEM-EDX samples were dispersed in ethanol with supersonic waves and dropped on carbon-coated Cu grids. X-ray adsorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were measured at the BL14B2 station at SPring-8 with the approval of the Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JASRI), proposal No. 2017B1842. The catalyst samples were put into plastic cuvette with optical length of 2 mm under air. The spectra were collected in transmission mode. Two ion chambers for I 0 and I were used, and the former was filled with 85% N2 + 15% Ar and 100% Ar for Pt L 3-edge and Pd K-edge measurements, respectively. The latter chamber was filled with 50% N2 + 50% Ar and 70% Ar + 30% Kr for Pt L 3-edge and Pd K-edge measurements, respectively. The edge jumps were in the range from 0.35 to 0.8. The data analyses of XANES and EXAFS were performed by using REX 2000 ver. 2.6.0 (Rigaku Corp.) program. For curve fitting analysis, the empirical phase shift and amplitude functions were extracted from data of reference compounds. Hanning window with dk = 0.05 was applied before Fourier transformation. The error range of the fitting was estimated by stepping the parameter until the residual factor (R f) becomes two times of the optimized value [37]. The reaction conditions for characterizations of used catalysts were p-cresol (1.9 mmol), 50 wt% CH3COOHaq (9.8 g), Pt/C (0.175 g; 0.09 mmol), Pd(CH3COO)2 (0 or 35 mg; 0 or 0.16 mmol), air (0.5 MPa), 353 K and 1 h. The leaching amount of metal species was determined by analyzing the filtrate of the reaction solution with ICP-AES (Thermo Fisher Scientific iCAP 6500). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Oxidation of p-cresol We selected p-cresol as the substrate for the exploration of the effective catalyst for alkylphenol oxidations because of the simple structure. We explored catalyst combinations of Pt/C and various co-catalysts, because Pt is known to be an effective catalyst among noble metals for non-free-radical oxidation reactions under acidic conditions such as alcohol oxidation [38–40]. We use aqueous acetic acid as the solvent because of the dissolution ability of alkylphenols and the resistance to oxidation. The results of oxidation of p-cresol with catalyst mixtures of Pt/C and various co-catalysts are shown in Table 1 . Pt/C without co-catalyst promoted the conversion of p-cresol (Table 1, entries 1 and 2); however, the yield of oxidation products of alkyl group (p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde and p-hydroxybenzoic acid) was very low. Among various noble metal species as co-catalysts (entries 3–8), Pd(CH3COO)2 showed the highest yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (entry 3), and salts of other metals did not produce p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (entries 6–8). The combinations with Pd(NO3)2 or Pd/C gave some amount of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (entries 4 and 5); however, the yields were lower than that with Pd(CH3COO)2. Formation of p-hydroxybenzoic acid was negligible for all runs. Next, the catalyst combinations of Pd(CH3COO)2 and various noble metals were tested, and the results are also shown in Table 1. Pd(CH3COO)2 alone showed low activity in p-cresol conversion and the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was negligible (entry 9). The combinations of Pd(CH3COO)2 with Rh/C, Ru/C or Ir/C also did not show formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (entries 12–14). The combination of Pd(CH3COO)2 and Pd/C showed some p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation (entry 11); however, the yield was lower than that with the combination of Pd(CH3COO)2 and Pt/C. The use of Pd/C alone gave very small amount of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde (entry 15). Bimetallic Pt-Pd/C catalysts were prepared and also tested; however, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was hardly produced over the bimetallic catalysts (entries 16 and 17). Therefore, the combination of Pt/C and Pd(CH3COO)2 (entry 3) is the best catalyst for oxidation of methyl group of p-cresol in the tested ones. Next, the reaction conditions were optimized. The effects of air pressure, reaction time and reaction temperature were shown in Table 2 . The air pressure has little effect on the activity and p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield (Table 2, entries 1–6). This trend is different from the typical one for free-radical autoxidation mechanism where positive reaction order is observed for alkylbenzene oxidation around 0.1 MPa of oxygen partial pressure [35,36,41,42]. Zero-reaction order with respect to oxygen pressure is often reported for noble-metal-catalyzed oxidation of alcohols, where hydride abstraction of adsorbed alcohol is the rate-determining step [43,44]. The dependence on the reaction time at 353 K (entries 2, 5, 7–9) showed that overoxidation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde slowly proceeded after p-cresol was almost totally converted. The highest yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was 35% which was obtained at 4 h (entry 7). The reaction temperature much affected the reaction results. At 333 K, the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was very slow (entry 10). At 373 K (entries 11 and 12), p-cresol was totally converted at 2 h (entry 11), and the yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was much lower than the case at 353 K. The yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde at 373 K became almost half during the next 2 h (2 to 4 h; entry 12). The low yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde at high temperature may be due to the intense polymerization of products. Table 3 shows the effect of Pd(CH3COO)2 amount. Larger amount of Pd(CH3COO)2 increased the p-cresol conversion, although too much Pd(CH3COO)2 amount decreased the p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield. Table 4 shows the effect of water/acetic acid ratio of the solvent. The use of pure acetic acid as solvent did not produce p-hydroxybenzaldehyde at all, indicating that water is necessary in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. The ratio around 1:1 was the most appropriate, and higher water/acetic acid ratio decreased the selectivity. After all, the best p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield was 35%, which was obtained in 50 wt% aqueous acetic acid, Pt on carbon : Pd(CH3COO)2 weight ratio = 1 : 2, at 353 K. This yield value of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde is much higher than those reported in the literature for oxidation of p-cresol in the absence of base: 9% with Cu(OAc)2 catalyst in ethylene glycol solvent [13], no reaction with N,N’-ethylenebis(acetylacetoniminato)-cobalt(II) hexafluorophosphoric pyridinium complex catalyst in ethylene glycol monoethyl ether solvent [15], and no reaction of 2-methoxy-p-cresol with CoOx@nitrogen-doped-carbon catalyst in ethylene glycol monoethyl ether solvent [16]. Oxidations of other alkylphenols, which have been rarely tested in the literature systems, were carried out with Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts system (Table 5 ). The yield of aldehyde or ketone was lower than the case of p-cresol oxidation (35% yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde), and loss of carbon balance was similarly large. The yield of o-hydroxybenzaldehyde from o-cresol was 9.9%. Much lower yield of o-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield than that of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde from the corresponding cresol has been also reported in Co + base catalyst system [14,29]. The yields of ketone from p-alkylphenols were decreased with increase of the length of alkyl chain: 10% p-hydroxyacetophenone from p-ethylphenol, and 7.2% p-hydroxypropiophenone from p-propylphenol. Both the reactivity and aldehyde yield of m-cresol was even much lower than p- and o-alkylphenols. 3.2 Catalyst stability The reusability of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts system was investigated. The catalysts were recovered by centrifugation and washed with 2-propanol. The dried catalysts were used in the next run. ICP-AES analysis indicated that almost all of Pd species, as well as Pt species, were recovered by this simple procedure (<0.2% loss of initial amount). The Pd species, which was initially added as soluble acetate, were attached on the solid Pt/C catalyst. The reaction results over recovered catalysts are shown in Table 6 . The recovered catalyst had some activity; however, the p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield was gradually decreased during reuses. The loss of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation activity cannot be explained by the leaching, and therefore the structure change and/or the poisoning deactivated the catalysts. 3.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of as-received Pt/C and catalysts after reaction are shown in Fig. 1 . As-received Pt/C showed weak sharp peaks for fcc Pt metal, and the particle size was calculated to be 10 nm by Sherrer’s equation. The Pt/C catalyst after reaction showed broad signal for fcc Pt metal, in addition to the sharp signals which were also present in as-received Pt/C. This result suggested that small Pt particles were formed during the reaction, in spite of the pressurized air atmosphere. The mechanism of the reduction to metal in this oxidative atmosphere will be discussed in the next section. In the case of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after reaction, more strong signals for fcc metal were observed, indicating that Pd species as well as Pt were reduced during the reaction. However, the peak positions for Pd and Pt are very similar and thus it is not clear whether alloy was formed or not from these data. In the case of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after 4 uses, the width of the strong peak became sharper than the case after the one use, indicating that metal particles were sintered during the reaction. This sintering can be related to the decrease of activity in p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation during reuses. To confirm the formation of metal particles during the oxidation reaction, we carried out TEM analyses. Fig. 2 A shows the TEM image of Pt/C alone after catalytic use. In addition to few large (>5 nm) particles, many small particles with the size of ∼2 nm were observed, which agreed with the XRD pattern. Fig. 2B-D shows the TEM-EDX images of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after one catalytic use. In addition to many small particles, which were also present in Pt/C after catalytic use, large particles (10–30 nm) with irregular shape were observed. They were probably aggregates of Pd metal particles, considering the EDX mapping (Fig. 2D) and XRD. The EDX mapping for Pt (Fig. 2C) showed that Pt was also present in or near the metal aggregates. However, the resolution of these TEM-EDX analyses was not high enough to distinguish between Pt-Pd alloy and aggregates of Pt and Pd particles. We further carried out XAFS (EXAFS and XANES) analysis of catalysts, because EXAFS can distinguish between the formations of monometallic and alloy particles. The Pt L 3-edge XANES spectra and Fourier transform of EXAFS spectra are shown in Fig. 3 A and B, respectively. The curve fitting results of Pt L 3-edge EXAFS are shown in Table 7 . The EXAFS oscillations and fitted spectra are shown in Figure S1, Supplementary Material. The XANES spectra showed that as-received Pt/C catalyst was partially oxidized, and it was reduced during the reaction. The EXAFS analysis also gave the same conclusions: Both Pt-Pt and Pt-O bonds were detected in as-received Pt/C, and only Pt-Pt bond was detected in Pt/C after catalytic use. These results agree with the other characterizations (XRD, TEM). For Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts after reaction, the Pt species was similarly reduced to the metallic state from both XANES and EXAFS data. An important point is that Pt-Pt shell alone can fit the EXAFS spectrum of used Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2, and Pt-Pd bond was not detected. In fact, curve fitting with Pt-Pd bond, theoretical function of which was calculated with FEFF program [45], instead of Pt-Pt bond could not well reproduce the spectrum (Table S1, Supplementary Material). The Pd K-edge XAFS spectra are shown in Fig. 4 and Figure S2 (Supplementary Material), and the curve fitting results are shown in Table 8 . The XANES spectra and the absence of Pd-O bond in EXAFS analysis showed that the Pd species in used Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 were totally reduced to the metallic state. The EXAFS data can be well fitted by only Pd-Pd shell, and Pd-Pt bond was not detected. Similarly to the Pt L 3-edge, curve fitting with Pd-Pt bond could not reproduce the Pd K-edge spectrum (Table S2, Supplementary Material). The absence of Pt-Pd bond in both Pt L 3-edge and Pd K-edge EXAFS analyses indicated that the formation of Pt-Pd alloy was negligible in Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts. The negligible involvement of Pt-Pd alloy in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde is also supported by the reaction results with bimetallic Pt-Pd/C catalysts. The selectivity to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde was decreased in the order of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 (standard; entry 3 in Table 1) >> Pt-Pd/C(N) (entry 17) > Pt-Pd/C(Cl) (entry 16). According to the XRD patterns (Figure S3, Supplementary Material), Pt-Pd/C(N) contained both Pt-rich and Pd-rich metal phases, and Pt-Pd/C(Cl) contained alloy phase with more homogeneity in composition. The low performance of Pt-Pd/C(Cl) in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde suggests the low activity of Pt-Pd alloy. Fig. 5 is the model structure of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts during the reaction based on the characterization results. The Pd(CH3COO)2 was reduced to the metallic state (Pd°) and deposited near the Pt particles. Smaller Pt particles were also formed, and dispersed on carbon support. Since Pd metal can be oxidized with air, the oxidation and reduction can be repeated during the oxidation reactions. The oxidation-reduction cycle can lead to sintering of Pd metal particles. 3.4 Reaction mechanism In order to check whether free-radical autoxidation mechanism was involved in Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts system or not, the reaction tests with radical scavenger were carried out. As shown in Table 9 , additions of typical radical scavenger, 2,6-di-tert-butyl-p-cresol or hydroquinone, do not significantly affect the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde from cresol, suggesting that free-radical autoxidation mechanism was not involved. The small dependence of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde on the air pressure (Table 2) also suggests the non-free-radical mechanism. Now we propose the reaction mechanism based on the reaction results and characterization. The catalyst survey in Table 1 indicates that all the systems that can produce p-hydroxybenzaldehyde from p-cresol contain Pd species (Pt/C + Pd compounds, Pd/C + Pd(CH3COO)2, and Pd/C), and all systems that do not contain Pd were inactive in the production of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. From the characterization results, the Pd species in Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 were metallic Pd° during the reaction, and, of course, Pd/C contains metallic Pd°. After all, only the systems that contain Pd° have activity in the production of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde, and therefore Pd° is likely to be the active species. Considering the general tendency that Pd° is not stable and is oxidized to Pd2+ in oxidative conditions [39], the role of Pt is probably to promote the reduction of Pd2+. Now the issue is the reductant for metal reduction. The loaded organic substances (acetic acid, p-cresol and carbon as the support) were not effective reductants for Pd2+. One possibility of the reductant is p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol which is an intermediate of p-cresol oxidation to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. We carried out control experiment for the reaction of Pd(CH3COO)2 solution with p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol in the presence of carbon support under inert atmosphere at 353 K. However, the XRD pattern of the recovered solid showed the formation of only small amount of Pd metal (Fig. 6 (b)), indicating that p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol is not an effective reducing agent for Pd(CH3COO)2 into Pd metal. Next, we carried out another control experiment for the reaction of oxidation product of p-cresol over Pt/C with Pd(CH3COO)2: p-cresol was oxidized over Pt/C under standard reaction conditions (the same as Table 1, entry 2). As described earlier, the reaction mixture only contained products that could not be detected by GC, i.e. polymerized products. Pd(CH3COO)2 was added to this mixture, and heated at 353 K (standard reaction temperature) under inert atmosphere. The XRD of the recovered catalyst (Fig. 6(d)) showed the same pattern of Pt/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 after standard reaction of p-cresol (Fig. 6(e)), indicating that Pd metal was formed. Therefore, the oxidation product of p-cresol over Pt/C can reduce Pd(CH3COO)2 to Pd metal. The overall scheme is shown in Fig. 7 . First, small amount of p-cresol is oxidized to polymeric species over Pt catalyst. The produced polymeric species reduces Pd2+ to Pd°, and the Pd metal particles are deposited near the Pt particles. After that, the formed Pd° particles are mainly responsible to the oxidation of p-cresol to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. Considering the low effect of air pressure on the reaction rate, the oxidation of p-cresol over Pd surface might proceed via C-H dissociation on metal surface, rather than via the reaction of activated oxygen species with the substrate. The metal-bound hydrogen species is quickly oxidized by oxygen to produce water. The chemisorbed p-cresol species also quickly oxygenated to give finally p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. The source of oxygen atom may be molecular oxygen via surface oxygen species or water molecule (cf. Wacker reaction). The involvement of water molecule can explain the necessity of water in the solvent as shown in Table 4; however, at this point there is no direct evidence for the reaction of surface species and water. Labelling study will give information for the source of oxygen atom. The formation of polymeric species is also catalyzed by Pd(0), because Pd/C alone or Pd/C + Pd(CH3COO)2 system gave also large amount of such products (Table 1, entries 11 and 15). Another side reaction is the oxidation of Pd° to PdO or Pd(CH3COO)2. Although these oxidized Pd species can be re-reduced to Pd° by the reactive polymeric products, the oxidation-reduction cycle can lead to the sintering of the aggregates of Pd metal particles. At present, optimization of the catalyst structure is not complete; the dispersed Pt particles located far from Pd° particles may not be involved in the p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation. Further development of Pt°-Pd° composite catalyst may increase the performance. 4 Conclusions This is the first report for the oxidation of the benzylic position of p-alkylphenols with air in the acidic conditions. The combination of Pt/C and Pd(CH3COO)2 catalyzes this oxidation in aqueous acetic acid solvent. Because of the intense formation of black polymeric by-products, the yield of the target carbonyl compound was still not high; the highest obtained yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde from p-cresol was 35%. Non-free-radical mechanism is involved in this oxidation system. The metal species were totally reduced to each metallic state in the reaction media even in these oxidizing conditions. The main active species for the oxidation is considered to be the Pd° species deposited on the carbon support, and the formation of Pd° is assisted by Pt: Oxidized polymeric products of p-cresol formed over Pt/C can be the reductant for Pd2+ to Pd°. The formation of Pt-Pd alloy was negligible, and the Pt-Pd bimetallic catalyst prepared by co-impregnation has rather lower performance in production of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. coredata.dc:description: Oxidation of benzylic position in alkylphenols with molecular oxygen in acidic conditions, which is very difficult because of the intense dimerization or polymerization, was investigated with various combinations of noble metal catalysts. The combination of Pt/C and Pd(CH3COO)2 catalysts showed activity in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde formation from p-cresol. The best p-hydroxybenzaldehyde yield was 35%, which was obtained in 50 wt% aqueous acetic acid, Pt on carbon : Pd(CH3COO)2 weight ratio = 1 : 2, at 353 K. From XRD, TEM-EDX and XAFS characterizations, the Pt and Pd species were totally reduced to Pt and Pd metal particles, respectively, in spite of the oxidative reaction conditions. Polymerized products (“tar”) of p-cresol formed with Pt/C catalyst and air can be the reductants for Pd(CH3COO)2 into Pd metal. The catalysts or catalyst combinations without Pd metal showed no activity in the formation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde, suggesting that Pd° is the active species. The effects of the air pressure and presence of radical scavenger were very small, suggesting that non-free-radical mechanism was involved.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of alkyl chain in alkylphenols over combination of Pt and Pd catalysts
